qas.question: What type of tree has resin that makes it stronger when it dries?
What's the funny name for resin-saturated heartwood?
What is fat lighter practically impervious to in addition to termites?
If spruce is shot full of crude resin and dried, which of its properties is increased?
Since it's highly flammable, what do people often use little pieces of longleaf pine tree stumps for?

context: Some experiments on very resinous <a0_0>Longleaf Pine<a0_0/> specimens indicate an increase in strength, due to the resin which increases the strength when dry. Such resin-saturated heartwood is called "<a1_0>fat lighter<a1_0/>". Structures built of fat lighter are almost impervious to <a2_0>rot<a2_0/> and termites; however they are very flammable. Stumps of old longleaf pines are often dug, split into small pieces and sold as <a4_0>kindling<a4_0/> for fires. Stumps thus dug may actually remain a century or more since being cut. Spruce impregnated with crude resin and dried is also greatly increased in <a3_0>strength<a3_0/> thereby.
